text.text: Welcome to the Device Management Digital Lounge!

blocks.alt_text: A multi-colored briefcase on a black background

text.text: Welcome to the WWDC22 Device Management Digital Lounge! We’ve got an exciting week planned for you. You can find the full schedule of events in the <https://developer.apple.com/news/?id=o6hq8cph|Apple Developer app and on  developer.apple.com>, and activities for all lounges kick off on June 7.
If you haven't already, please take a moment to familiarize yourself with <https://developer.apple.com/news/?id=735utu4s|how the Digital Lounges will work>.

We want to make sure these spaces are helpful and welcoming for everyone — developers and Apple employees alike. Please review and follow the <https://developer.apple.com/wwdc22/policies/interactive-events/1/Apple-Developer-WWDC22-Interactive-Events-Attendance-Policy.pdf| WWDC22 Interactive Events Policy>.

messages.text: Welcome to Q&A: Device Management! We’ve got a large team ready, and we’re looking forward to answering all of your device management-related questions. You should see a (+) button with a lightning bolt at the lower left. From there, select “Ask a question”. Your question will be delivered directly to our team, and we’ll repost and answer as many of them as we can! If you have a followup, whether or not you originally asked the question, you can add it directly in the thread. While we may not be able to address every question, we value each and every one of them; thank you for spending your time with us!

elements.text: Welcome to Q&A: Device Management! We’ve got a large team ready, and we’re looking forward to answering all of your device management-related questions. You should see a (+) button with a lightning bolt at the lower left. From there, select “Ask a question”. Your question will be delivered directly to our team, and we’ll repost and answer as many of them as we can! If you have a followup, whether or not you originally asked the question, you can add it directly in the thread. While we may not be able to address every question, we value each and every one of them; thank you for spending your time with us!

messages.text: Note that if you have questions you’d like to ask privately, or are unique to your particular environment, please consider signing up for a session in our Custom app distribution and device management lab on Wednesday from 2-5PM PDT and Thursday 9AM-12PM PDT.

elements.text: Note that if you have questions you’d like to ask privately, or are unique to your particular environment, please consider signing up for a session in our Custom app distribution and device management lab on Wednesday from 2-5PM PDT and Thursday 9AM-12PM PDT.

messages.text: Without further ado, let’s get to it!

elements.text: Without further ado, let’s get to it!

messages.text:
<@U03JKDJMFL4> asked
> Does the given workflow of enabling Enrollment SSO also work with Automated Device Enrollment or will this be a User Enrollment feature only?

elements.Raw: {"type":"rich_text_quote","elements":[{"type":"text","text":"Does the given workflow of enabling Enrollment SSO also work with Automated Device Enrollment or will this be a User Enrollment feature only?"}]}

slackdump_thread_replies.text: This is only for User Enrollments. Automated Device Enrollments are not supported.

elements.text: This is only for User Enrollments. Automated Device Enrollments are not supported.

slackdump_thread_replies.text: What kind of experience were you looking for here? I presume this would be a case where you're requiring a user to authenticate as part of the ADE enrollment process? So you'd want to trigger the ESSO app download while still in Setup Assistant?

elements.text: What kind of experience were you looking for here? I presume this would be a case where you're requiring a user to authenticate as part of the ADE enrollment process? So you'd want to trigger the ESSO app download while still in Setup Assistant?

slackdump_thread_replies.text: Yes, that's pretty much it. We would like to mirror the process as much as possible. It makes these processes easier to train to other admins, more convenient to debug, and causes less technical debt.

elements.text: Yes, that's pretty much it. We would like to mirror the process as much as possible. It makes these processes easier to train to other admins, more convenient to debug, and causes less technical debt.

slackdump_thread_replies.text: I want the enrollment through ADE to also setup the Authenticator at the same time. So, for example, you would use Okta Verify to perform enrollment so that the user wouldn't have to authenticate twice to get an SSO experience
I had the same question as Scott for the same reason - less overhead for our support folks and less moving parts to potentially go wrong.

elements.text: I had the same question as Scott for the same reason - less overhead for our support folks and less moving parts to potentially go wrong.

slackdump_thread_replies.text: Largely the same here — ADE, acquire and do SSO during Setup Assistant, for building and signon of the new end user account.

elements.text: Largely the same here — ADE, acquire and do SSO during Setup Assistant, for building and signon of the new end user account.

<@U03JKDJMFL4> asked
> In the video, there was a code example of enrollment-sso.json. Is this filename and location fixed or will we be able to specify a location for the json file? Are there any naming convention restrictions or domain restrictions like we have with Account Driven User Enrollments?

elements.Raw: {"type":"rich_text_quote","elements":[{"type":"text","text":"In the video, there was a code example of enrollment-sso.json. Is this filename and location fixed or will we be able to specify a location for the json file? Are there any naming convention restrictions or domain restrictions like we have with Account Driven User Enrollments?"}]}

slackdump_thread_replies.text: There are no restrictions on the URL, beyond it being an https URL. Typically the Enrollment SSO document would be hosted by the server processing the user enrollment flow (which itself is likely to be the MDM server).

elements.text: There are no restrictions on the URL, beyond it being an https URL. Typically the Enrollment SSO document would be hosted by the server processing the user enrollment flow (which itself is likely to be the MDM server).

slackdump_thread_replies.text: So this is not a user-crafted file like with the Account Driven workflow?

elements.text: So this is not a user-crafted file like with the Account Driven workflow?

slackdump_thread_replies.text: The enrollment SSO document contains data specific to the MDM service and will likely be auto-generated by MDM servers that support the new feature.

elements.text: The enrollment SSO document contains data specific to the MDM service and will likely be auto-generated by MDM servers that support the new feature.

messages.text:
<@U03JRBCTDTN> asked
> Will there be a pass key implementation for enterprise that has iCloud Keychain disabled due to data governance?

elements.Raw: {"type":"rich_text_quote","elements":[{"type":"text","text":"Will there be a pass key implementation for enterprise that has iCloud Keychain disabled due to data governance?"}]}

slackdump_thread_replies.text:
Passkeys require iCloud Keychain, which works with Apple IDs. Managed Apple IDs are typically used in organizational contexts, because organizations often require administrative control over accounts. iCloud Keychain is not supported for Managed Apple IDs.

That said, please submit feedback for any feature requests you have related to this topic (passkeys in the enterprise)!

elements.text:
Passkeys require iCloud Keychain, which works with Apple IDs. Managed Apple IDs are typically used in organizational contexts, because organizations often require administrative control over accounts. iCloud Keychain is not supported for Managed Apple IDs.

That said, please submit feedback for any feature requests you have related to this topic (passkeys in the enterprise)!

messages.text:
<@U03JYHSL6AD> asked
> Documentation says the System Preferences profile type is being deprecated. Do you have an ETA on a replacement for the new System Settings interface? There are still specific pieces that we may need to disable from machines, especially in environments such as labs.

elements.Raw: {"type":"rich_text_quote","elements":[{"type":"text","text":"Documentation says the System Preferences profile type is being deprecated. Do you have an ETA on a replacement for the new System Settings interface? There are still specific pieces that we may need to disable from machines, especially in environments such as labs."}]}

slackdump_thread_replies.text: We are not planning offer a replacement to the System Preferences payload. The current payload has been setup to do a mapping to grey out the areas it used in System Preferences. What we would like to do in is introduce additional restrictions or new payloads to manage settings that need to be managed. Please file feedback to let us know what specific feature you need to manage.

elements.text: We are not planning offer a replacement to the System Preferences payload. The current payload has been setup to do a mapping to grey out the areas it used in System Preferences. What we would like to do in is introduce additional restrictions or new payloads to manage settings that need to be managed. Please file feedback to let us know what specific feature you need to manage.

slackdump_thread_replies.text: Based on what I’ve seen so far, I like the greyed-out implementation of things that were blocked in System Preferences.

elements.text: Based on what I’ve seen so far, I like the greyed-out implementation of things that were blocked in System Preferences.

slackdump_thread_replies.text: Thanks Graham! We haven’t completed testing on that part yet, but a mapping should do for now. I’ll open some feedback further into the cycle about our workflows to feed into those new settings.

elements.text: Thanks Graham! We haven’t completed testing on that part yet, but a mapping should do for now. I’ll open some feedback further into the cycle about our workflows to feed into those new settings.

messages.text:
<@U03JKBMD25R> asked
> For a small company with maybe 10 users large MDM solutions seem not to be the perfect solution for software distribution. Yet, asking employees, who bring their own devices, to spend hundreds of euros / dollars on apps for business use is not the perfect solution. Is there a recommended way from Apple for a company to buy apps for users, that they can use in their personal Apple IDs and their store accounts?

elements.Raw: {"type":"rich_text_quote","elements":[{"type":"text","text":"For a small company with maybe 10 users large MDM solutions seem not to be the perfect solution for software distribution. Yet, asking employees, who bring their own devices, to spend hundreds of euros \/ dollars on apps for business use is not the perfect solution. Is there a recommended way from Apple for a company to buy apps for users, that they can use in their personal Apple IDs and their store accounts?"}]}

slackdump_thread_replies.text: Volume app purchases in Apple Business Manager can be transferred to employees using redemption codes. The license transfers to the employee's personal Apple ID in that case.  Managed app distribution (either device based or user based) with MDM allows you to revoke and reassign licenses and the company retains ownership of the license.

elements.text: Volume app purchases in Apple Business Manager can be transferred to employees using redemption codes. The license transfers to the employee's personal Apple ID in that case.  Managed app distribution (either device based or user based) with MDM allows you to revoke and reassign licenses and the company retains ownership of the license.

<@U03JYHSL6AD> asked
> With Platform SSO, the session mentioned that if the IdP password changes, the new password is verified "on unlock." Does this indicate that the user's local account password is sync'd, or is the verification only within the SSO extension and not affecting the local account ("offline" credentials if you will excuse the reference)?

elements.Raw: {"type":"rich_text_quote","elements":[{"type":"text","text":"With Platform SSO, the session mentioned that if the IdP password changes, the new password is verified \"on unlock.\" Does this indicate that the user's local account password is sync'd, or is the verification only within the SSO extension and not affecting the local account (\"offline\" credentials if you will excuse the reference)?"}]}

slackdump_thread_replies.text:
The local account password is synced when possible with the password.

On unlock, if the password is different than the local account password, it’s synced it if it verifies with the IdP.

messages.text:
<@U03JYHSL6AD> asked
> The new priority key for OS updates is very interesting, and I have two questions about it. First, does setting "High" cause a reboot to be issued (similar to InstallNow) or only to download and prepare? Second, what is the behavior for "Low"? It was not mentioned.

elements.Raw: {"type":"rich_text_quote","elements":[{"type":"text","text":"The new priority key for OS updates is very interesting, and I have two questions about it. First, does setting \"High\" cause a reboot to be issued (similar to InstallNow) or only to download and prepare? Second, what is the behavior for \"Low\"? It was not mentioned."}]}

slackdump_thread_replies.text: The priority only changes the priority with which the download is accomplished. When high, it will be done ASAP. Otherwise, the download is discretionary and the system may defer the download to higher priority user activity.

elements.text: The priority only changes the priority with which the download is accomplished. When high, it will be done ASAP. Otherwise, the download is discretionary and the system may defer the download to higher priority user activity.

slackdump_thread_replies.text: Makes total sense, thank you! Does this affect the priority of the prepare operation and nice it down for low priority as well, or ONLY the download?

elements.text: Makes total sense, thank you! Does this affect the priority of the prepare operation and nice it down for low priority as well, or ONLY the download?

slackdump_thread_replies.text: Only the download. The prepare phase doesn't get throttled by the system.

elements.text: Only the download. The prepare phase doesn't get throttled by the system.

messages.text: Thank you all for joining us for this Q&A! We got a ton of questions, and we know we didn’t get to them all, but I hope you had as much fun as we did! While the party has to end for now, make sure to return for our future events! We have another Q&A session on *Thursday* at 8AM PDT. We have a Q&A dedicated to Declarative Device Management topics on *Wednesday* at 12PM PDT. And we have a Meet the Presenter session + Q&A where you can learn more about Managed Device Attestation on *Friday* at 9AM PDT. We also have Custom App Distribution and Device Management lab sessions on Wednesday from 2-5PM PDT and Thursday 9AM-12PM PDT. We hope to see you there!

messages.text: Welcome to Q&A: Declarative Device Management! We’ve got our team ready, and we’re looking forward to answering all of your questions about declarative device management. You should see a (+) button with a lightning bolt at the lower left. From there, select “Ask a question”. Your question will be delivered directly to our team, and we’ll repost and answer as many of them as we can! If you have a followup, whether or not you originally asked the question, you can add it directly in the thread. While we may not be able to address every question, we value each and every one of them; thank you for spending your time with us!

messages.text:
<@U03JRHQU54H> asked
> Is Apple going to provide anything to admins to easily convert configuration profiles to declarative management profiles or will MDM providers need to handle that?

elements.Raw: {"type":"rich_text_quote","elements":[{"type":"text","text":"Is Apple going to provide anything to admins to easily convert configuration profiles to declarative management profiles or will MDM providers need to handle that?"}]}

slackdump_thread_replies.text: We expect that will be up to MDM vendors to handle. There likely won't be a one-to-one mapping between profile keys and configuration keys, so a custom mapping will be needed. However, our new open source device management schema data (<https://github.com/apple/device-management>) , has machine readable versions of both profiles and configurations that should help with that process.

) , has machine readable versions of both profiles and configurations that should help with that process.

slackdump_thread_replies.text: App inventory is an obvious one. Inventory (especially version specific) is often tied to vuln scanning. So, automated security vulnerability scanning would be useful here. _Granted_ this is most useful for _all_ apps and not just those installed via MDM.

elements.text: App inventory is an obvious one. Inventory (especially version specific) is often tied to vuln scanning. So, automated security vulnerability scanning would be useful here.
apps and not just those installed via MDM.

slackdump_thread_replies.text: This is an interesting question, especially since it’s been stated that only MDM issued installations and status are monitored, but managed app states are definitely something we rely on now for compliance - and there are conditionals based on that status - but also include apps and processes outside what is managed. Predicates activating on-device conditionally, potentially shift a lot of how those rules are written - honestly it’s kind of difficult to envision. I think we’re all eager to see implementation by our respective MDM vendors to make this more tangible.

I think we’re all eager to see implementation by our respective MDM vendors to make this more tangible.

slackdump_thread_replies.text: Predicates use the NSPredicate syntax documented at <https://developer.apple.com/library/archive/documentation/Cocoa/Conceptual/Predicates/AdditionalChapters/Introduction.html>. messages.text: Welcome to Q&A: Device Management! We’ve got our cups of coffee, and we’re looking forward to answering all of your device management-related questions! You should see a (+) button with a lightning bolt at the lower left. From there, select “Ask a question”. Your question will be delivered directly to our team, and we’ll repost and answer as many of them as we can! If you have a followup, whether or not you originally asked the question, you can add it directly in the thread. While we may not be able to address every question, we value each and every one of them; thank you for spending your morning with us! Without further ado, let’s get to it!

messages.text:
<@U03K14UURA5> asked
> How's the behaviour for macOS Managed Software Updates during PowerNap or while asleep? Will it restart even when unsaved files are still open?

elements.Raw: {"type":"rich_text_quote","elements":[{"type":"text","text":"How's the behaviour for macOS Managed Software Updates during PowerNap or while asleep? Will it restart even when unsaved files are still open?"}]}

slackdump_thread_replies.text: The only difference is macOS will now acknowledge the commands when sent while in power nap mode. All other existing software update rules will still apply. InstallForceRestart will be the only install action to force install while files are opened.

elements.text: The only difference is macOS will now acknowledge the commands when sent while in power nap mode. All other existing software update rules will still apply. InstallForceRestart will be the only install action to force install while files are opened.

slackdump_thread_replies.text: Thank you!

messages.text:
<@U03JYHSL6AD> asked
> The Platform SSO overview mentioned that a user being disabled in the linked IdP does not prevent login. Can you describe what the behavior is for the user in this situation?

elements.Raw: {"type":"rich_text_quote","elements":[{"type":"text","text":"The Platform SSO overview mentioned that a user being disabled in the linked IdP does not prevent login. Can you describe what the behavior is for the user in this situation?"}]}

slackdump_thread_replies.text: Because the local account exists on the Mac already, the user will still be able to login to this local account even though the account has been disabled in the IdP.

elements.text: Because the local account exists on the Mac already, the user will still be able to login to this local account even though the account has been disabled in the IdP.

slackdump_thread_replies.text: The last password that synced remains. In a scenario where the user should no longer be able to login to the device, other methods should be used such as the device lock MDM command.

elements.text: The last password that synced remains. In a scenario where the user should no longer be able to login to the device, other methods should be used such as the device lock MDM command.

slackdump_thread_replies.text: Ok, got it - so the user doesn’t really “know” and there’s no warning about it? I’m thinking about accidental disable/mistakes as well as for terminations of employees here.

elements.text: Ok, got it - so the user doesn’t really “know” and there’s no warning about it? I’m thinking about accidental disable/mistakes as well as for terminations of employees here.

slackdump_thread_replies.text: Think of this like a local password that just happens to get automatically updated/kept in sync. But it's still a local password and therefore still behaves exactly as any other local password would — since that's what it is. So in those cases you're talking about, you'll want to handle it separately.

elements.text: Think of this like a local password that just happens to get automatically updated/kept in sync. But it's still a local password and therefore still behaves exactly as any other local password would — since that's what it is. So in those cases you're talking about, you'll want to handle it separately.

messages.text:
<@U03JZ6YGT7C> asked
> We're using Jamf Connect in our environment to sync the IDP password (AzureAD) to the local Mac password, but per company initiatives toward a Zero Trust environment, we're looking at separating the local Mac password from the IDP password, similar to Windows Hello for Business. It sounds like Platform SSO, in this iteration, will only do password synching. Would it be possible to make the password synching optional?

elements.Raw: {"type":"rich_text_quote","elements":[{"type":"text","text":"We're using Jamf Connect in our environment to sync the IDP password (AzureAD) to the local Mac password, but per company initiatives toward a Zero Trust environment, we're looking at separating the local Mac password from the IDP password, similar to Windows Hello for Business. It sounds like Platform SSO, in this iteration, will only do password synching. Would it be possible to make the password synching optional?"}]}

slackdump_thread_replies.text: You do not need to use password auth / password syncing. You can configure Platform SSO to use a Secure Enclave-backed key for user authentication to the IdP, instead of password-based auth. The IdP must have implemented support for this. But assuming it has, then this will give you (and the user) the desired experience.

elements.text: You do not need to use password auth / password syncing. You can configure Platform SSO to use a Secure Enclave-backed key for user authentication to the IdP, instead of password-based auth. The IdP must have implemented support for this. But assuming it has, then this will give you (and the user) the desired experience.

messages.text:
<@U03JDKKJN1K> asked
> What is the infrastructure for an ACME server? Consider if in the beginning, MDA is only utilized by Apple devices and not of general interest to other platforms. Would it be a product that MDM cloud vendors could provide? Will it need to be provided by our enterprise infrastructure team to host and network security team to configure? Where is Microsoft in providing ACME services?

elements.Raw: {"type":"rich_text_quote","elements":[{"type":"text","text":"What is the infrastructure for an ACME server? Consider if in the beginning, MDA is only utilized by Apple devices and not of general interest to other platforms. Would it be a product that MDM cloud vendors could provide? Will it need to be provided by our enterprise infrastructure team to host and network security team to configure? Where is Microsoft in providing ACME services?"}]}

slackdump_thread_replies.text:
> What is the infrastructure for an ACME server?
The infrastructure would be an ACME server that incorporates support for the new IETF draft seen here: <https://datatracker.ietf.org/doc/draft-bweeks-acme-device-attest/>

> Consider if in the beginning, MDA is only utilized by Apple devices and not of general interest to other platforms.
If you take a look at the new IETF draft you'll notice it is meant to support the attestation formats of multiple platforms, not just Apple devices.

> Would it be a product that MDM cloud vendors could provide?
There's many possibilities for who runs the ACME server. A likely case is MDM cloud vendors — today, the vast majority of MDM cloud vendors have a CA built in to their products, and implement for SCEP protocol for certificate requests and issuance. If they wanted to implement support for Managed Device Attestation, they would add support for ACME protocol alongside their existing SCEP support.

> Will it need to be provided by our enterprise infrastructure team to host and network security team to configure?
If you are using a cloud based MDM vendor, then answer is probably "no" (see above answer). The exception would be customers with unique environments or needs, who for whatever reason choose to host their own Certificate Authority for issuing client certs. But that model has declined in popularity over time with the industry-wide shift towards cloud-based MDM solutions.

> Where is Microsoft in providing ACME services?
We can't comment on the roadmaps of other companies — we suggest reaching out to the vendors who you would like to see adopt ACME protocol and Managed Device Attestation.

<@U03HWHSA6KY> asked
> Safari per app VPN and AssociatedDomains payload configuration is hard to apply in most real world cases (except custom apps).  But for apps like Slack, Salesforce, Zendesk, and pretty much all popular SaaS apps its almost impossible to specify all the domains that should be associated with the VPN.  In effect, this causes us to recommend Chrome or some other browser as a managed app for these use cases but users obviously prefer Safari.  
> 
> Are there any plans to improve this?  Having a 2nd Safari that is Managed (similar to Android work profiles that allows install of 2nd instance of Chrome) would be great but even a better way to configure AssociatedDomains based on address bar url (rather than ALL http requests domains) would be a major step forward.

messages.text: We've gotten a few questions along the lines of: If User Enrollments don’t include device identifiers in the attestation certificate, how do servers know what they’re managing?

elements.text: We've gotten a few questions along the lines of: If User Enrollments don’t include device identifiers in the attestation certificate, how do servers know what they’re managing?

slackdump_thread_replies.text: User Enrollments don’t provide to the organization identifiers that outlive the enrollment. But the key pair for an ACME payload remains the same, so a server encountering the same public key at two different times can be confident that it’s the same device both times. Similarly, two different servers encountering the same public key can be confident that it’s the same device.

But the key pair for an ACME payload remains the same, so a server encountering the same public key at two different times can be confident that it’s the same device both times. Similarly, two different servers encountering the same public key can be confident that it’s the same device.
